solution.text:
Original number of engineers = \(_{{20*j}}_\)
Engineers who leave the team = \(_{{10*j}}_\)
Therefore, engineers remaining = \(_{{20*j}}_- _{{10*j}}_ = _{{10*j}}_\)
Since the numbers of engineers and number of days to finish the job are inversely proportional, we get:
\( _{{20*j}}_ \times _{{32*k}}_ \) = Constant
\(_{{10*j}}_ \times \) (Nunber of days to create the website a second time) = Constant
Therefore,\( _{{20*j}}_ \times _{{32*k}}_ = _{{10*j}}_ \times \) (Nunber of days to create the website a second time)
Nunber of days to create the website a second time =\( \frac {_{{32*k}}_ \times _{{20*j}}_}{_{{10*j}}_} \)
\(\Rightarrow\) Nunber of days to create the website a second time = \(_{{64*k}}_\)

content.text: You are the owner of a software company and are given a contract to create a website. It takes you \(_{{20*j}}_\) trained engineers and \(_{{32*k}}_\) days to finish the job. Unfortunately there is a problem and you must redo all the work again, but \(_{{10*j}}_\) engineers, disappointed with your management, leave your team. How much time will it take for the remaining engineers to recreate the website again?
